Who can tell the weight of all these fearful Curses which God hath in his righteous Law, de∣clared against those that are under the Guilt o Sin? ask those that have felt it, under the Ter∣rors of an awakened Conscience, and they will tell you, that if all the mountains in the World had lain upon them, it could not have been more heavy. It contains in it the Wrath of that God before whom the Devils tremble, whose Hand is Omnipotent, a frown of whose Countenance is able to dissole the Creation, whose Rebuke can blast the Creature at once, Psal. 31.11.

3. If therefore this Guilt abide on you, it will sink you into perdition. It will be your unavoid∣able and everlasting ruine; the fire of the Wrath which is kindled by it, will, if not put out by his grace, burn to the uttermost hell: it will never leave till it hath crushed you down into the bot∣tomless pit; however you may seem to stout it out for the present, you will certainly fall before
it, and a fearful fall it will give you. It will be a eadful thing to go out of the World under the Guilt of all that Sin which you are to be charged withal; and when you come to k over into Eternity, as ere long you will, and feel all your Sins lying on you, you would give ten thousand worlds, if you had them to dispose of, be delivered from under the weight of them. Oh that you would see and believe it!

2. Be advised to go to God for pardon. One would think that the consideration of the weight of Sin lying upon them, were enough to put Sinners on asking earnestly how they may get it moved: now be directed to ask it of God, and wait on him for it: And to move you here∣to, Consider;

1. There is no other way to be discharged of this burden. It is only by a pardon that it can done, and if you think of any other course, deceive your selves. As long as the Sen∣tence is out against you, dooming you to dy, and the Justice of God stands engaged to the Executi∣on of it, your sins do and will ly upon you. It is not all your legal repentances, reformations, stinences from the acts of sin, that will turn to y account; you are condemned still, except the Judgment be revoked; and what quiet or com∣fort can you enjoy as long as it is so? surely Sin must ly heavy, while you are in this condition

2. There is forgiveness with him: This is the ly relief against an accusing and condemning Conscience▪ Psal. 130.3, 4. How this comes to
be, and how wonderfully he hath laid in for it will be hereafter considered: but he hath a stoc of forgiveness; he can be just, and justify, Rom. 3.26. he can abundantly pardon, Isa. 55.7. and h alone can do it; there is none else in the world that can give you a pardon, but he: if he do not forgive you, if all the men and Angels in the world should do it, it would signify nothing a all.

3. He makes the offer of a pardon to you. He doth not only wait to see if you will come and ask it of him, but he sends to you a Message a∣bout it; he hath commanded that you should b told about it, and pleaded with to accept of it he hath sent an Embassy to you by his Servant who are to entreat you to entertain it, 2 Cor. 20. and he is, all this day of his patience, wai∣ing to see whether you will embrace it or no and why will ye dy? why will you not seek have your burden thus taken off, but rather chu to bear it, though it will overwhelm you in endless Destruction?

USE II. Let it be for Examination. Try we by this whether the burden of our Sins be indeed removed off from us. It is a very desirable thing to be known; and there is a Rule o judgment about it; be perswaded to be solemn in it. Hence consider;

1. There are those that are mistaken; they find ease upon their spirits, and they have an hope that their sins are discharged, they would
perswade themselves that they have received emission of them, when there is no such thing: and there are a great many cheats that Satan and their false hearts do put on them in this regard, and perswade them to cry peace to themselves when there is no peace. You have ed then to be very heedful in this respect.

2. A mistake on this account is very perilous. If whiles we please our selves with a dream of pardon, and peace, and quiet our selves in it, whiles we are indeed in the gall of bitterness, and bond of iniquity, we loose our opportunity of seek∣ing it, are held fast under our Guilt, and live in hazard every day of dropping into the pit from whence there is no delivery. Let us then take dili∣gent heed on this account, lest we rue it when too late; and for Rules of Trial.

1. Did you ever find Sin to be your great bur∣den? I know that the Spirit of God acts diversly as to the degrees of terror which he excites in the Consciences of those whom he Converts; am sure that he makes sin our burden in order to his taking of it off from us; an evil and a bitter thing, Jer. 2.19. he first lays it on in Conviction, before he removes it in pardon. I speak of those that grow to years of understan∣ding. If then you are strangers to this, and know not what it means, you have reason to think that your Guilt abides on you.

2. Have you truly gone to God for forgive∣ness? all other attempts are vain and unprofita∣ble; he hath it in his disposal, and will not
put it out of his own hands Jesus Christ, wh i God is the dispe of it, and the invitaton is to come to him if we would obtain it. Hav you so done? and if you have, you have relinquished all other objects of trust and confidence your former essays are no more pursued but rejected: he hath said that he will be sought to the house of Israel for this. Have you then heakened to his Call? and see that you be not mistaken in this; it is not every perfunctory prayer will prove it; it is not every pretended acceping of the offered pardon, that will amount this: there is a so coming requisite. Hence,

3. Have you cast your selves on free grace for it? There is a vast difference between a perso being acquitted upon a payment, and upon pardon. It may be you have thought you have mourned, repented, forsaken your sins, and now you have gone in reliance upon these for pardon this is a contradiction; a pardon is a free act one that hath the power to give it; and if you have gotten it, you went for it, with an alone reliance on that Grace of his, which was revealed to you for your encouragement: you went with∣out money, and without price: You have acknow∣ledged it to be an act of Soveraignty, and accor∣dingly have laid your selves down at the footstool of Soveraign Grace, by an humble resignation of your selves to that; and that hath been all your hope, because he is a pardoning God: you have ad∣dressed him as David, Psal. 25.11. For thy name sake, Oh Lord, pardon mine iniquity.

USE. III. Let this serve to encourage and irect burdened Souls, that are sinking under the apprehension, and oppression of the weight of Si ing upon them, in the Guilt of it. Here is that which may help to bear up your Spirits, and point you what to do, that you may may obtain a gra∣ous deliverance from it: and for encouragment, Consider;

1. There is a way for you to get ease upon this ccount, a pardon will do it. What though your ins be not altogether taken away, as to the pre∣ence and activity of them, yet if they may be for∣iven for the present, this is good relief in this uncture; this may satisfy your Consciences, and them of their distress; and will give you assurance that the other shall be done in due time oo.

2. There are no Sins so great or numerous, but may be thus removed. God is able to take them off, his forgiving Grace and Vertue is not limited; he vilest of Sinners may be encouraged to go to im for it; and if they do, he will in no wise ast them out: Sins that Lye as mountains between God and you▪ cannot stop his way from Coming and pardoning you.

3. It is a good sign that he intends you a par∣don, when he makes you feel your Sins to be an nsupportable burden. It is the way in which he hath been wont to dispense his Salvation to mise∣able Sinners. It looks like the beginning towards a good work of Saving Grace▪ the Spirit first
Convinceth of sin, Joh. 16.8. and that conviction will leave oppression upon the Soul: and hen the next and immediate invitation of the Gospel, is to such as are weary and heavy laden under such distress▪ Mat. 11.28. And for Direction.

1. Beware of flying to other courses to get ease▪ there are many, and we are apt to be tempte to them: Cains's course, Judas's course; the common course of the most, in seeking repair all by legal repentance and amendment, deceive you, and you shall find it labour vain.
2. Be sure to seek a pardon in Gods wa▪ As none can give it but he, so there is a wa in which he derives it to us, and you must oserve it; and attend upon it, if you would be deceived; and here,

1. Go to him with your Sins; there is a gre do that many make, they would go, but they so vile, and so unworthy, and hence th would get rid of their sins first: but this wi never be; if ever your sins be taken away, must do it, Hos. 14.2. and the first thing he doth in it, is to pardon them, on which th purging of them follows in order of nature▪ carry all with you, for all want a pardon.

2. Confess and bewail them before him; th is the way to obtain mercy at his hands, Prov. 2▪ 13. lay them all open before him, with all the aggravations to the utmost that you can. Th is the thing which God expects, and you mu not be short in it, but as full as you can. Ta
them upon your selves, and he will be ready to take them off.

3. Cry to him for Forgiveness; this should be the first great cry of a guilty Sinner, that God would take off that Guilt: and cry as those that are oppressed; let them be loud, earnest, importu∣nate, incessant cries; say as he did when he was sinking, Help, Lord, I perish. God expects that your prayers be sensible ones.

4. Now cast your burden upon him by Faith; throw your Sins upon his mercy, by laying hold on the Lord Jesus Christ, and his Righteousness. It is the advice, Psal. 55.22. Cast thy burden on the Lord; all burdens, none excepted, are here intended; and if this be the greatest of all, be sure to roll it on him; and if you do, you shall find his helping hand afforded to take it off, and give you rest.

DIV2.HEAD: Forgiveness Covereth Sin. DOCTRINE IV.
DIV2.P:
FOrgiveness casts a Cover over the Sins of him that is pardoned. This is the second expression by which this great benefit is set forth, the word a was observed, signifies, To hide a thing out of sight, throwing of some other thing over it, as we would by some nasty odious thing, which we would
not have seen. the clearing up of this Doct∣rine, we may enquire,
1. What is implied in the Covering of Sin?
2. Who it is that Covers it?
3 How or after what manner it is Covered?
4. What advantage to the person by having his Sin Covered?
1. What is implied Covering of Sin?

A. This phrase is used to express the For∣giveness of Sin, and is accordingly to be interpre∣ted. Now the reason why things are Covered, is that they may be hidden out of sight; that they may not always be in our eye and view to be looked on; and the end of our Covering a thing is either with respect to our selves or others. In regard to others, we Cover it, that they may not see or know it, thus, 1 Pet. 4.8. Charity shall cover the multitude of sins; i. e. it keeps them to it self, and doth not divulge them. Covering is opposed to discovering; thus when men bring pretences to put off things, they are said to cover them: excu∣ses are called Covers. With respect to our selves we are said to cover a thing, when we put it out of our sight, in order to the putting it out of our remem∣brance: and we are wont to do so by things, the sight and memory whereof would be a grief or a vexation to us; and thus are we here to under∣stand it. God covers his peoples sins from his own sight, that so he may not remember them, nor be angry at his Children by reason of them, so as to take vengeance on them upon the account thereof, the Scripture represents Sin as a thing
odious to God, a thing that he cannot endure to look upon, Hab. 1.13. a thing that horribly pro∣vokes him against the Sinner; and therefore cal∣led the abominable thing that he hates, Jer. 44.4. Hence, when he is resolved to punish men for it, he is said, to set it in his sight, Psal. 90.8 to make strict search after it, Zech. 1.12. To call it to remembrance, Ezek. 21.23. When therefore he comes to pardon it, it sets it forth by contrary expressions, the putting it away, 2 Sam. 12.13. Hi∣ding his face from beholding it, Psal. 51.9 not seeing it, Numb. 23.21. The removing it far from him, Psal. 103 12. Forgetting, or not remembring it any more, Isa. 43.25. Casting it into the depth of the Sea, Mic. 7.19. All of which expressions are of the same import with this of Covering them.

If it be here enquired, how can God be said to cover our Sin out of his sight? It must be re∣plied, that it is spoken after the manner of men, who are wont to forget, or take no notice of that which is laid out of the way. And here let us observe.

1. That nothing can be covered to God in re∣spect of his Omniscience. Heb. 4.13. There is no such veil of darkness can be cast over any thing that can intercept his sight, Psal. 139.11, 12. Gods Infinite Omnipresence necessarily infers that every thing must be in his eye, and it is im∣possible to abscond it from him, so as he shall not know it thoroughly; and equally impossible that he should forget it; we are on this account of∣ten warned to be cautious, because we are ever
under the inspection of his all seeing eye.

2. That God doth not so put their Sins out of his sight, but that he puts them in mind of them, and sometimes makes them smart for them; thus we have Job awfully complaining, Job 13.26. What a solemn memorial did he cause the Pro∣phet to mention to David? 2 Sam. 12.7, 8. and how much and how long did he make him to smart on this account afterwards? yea doutless all the Afflictions that are brought on the Children of God in way of Correction for their Sins, are witnesses that he hath an eye upon them, or a re∣membrance of them in a disciplinary way; Hence,
3. This covering them properly respects Vin∣dictive Justice, or the Sentence of the Law which is out against them; and that is the Guilt that cleaves to them, and it is a pardon that doth it▪ For,
1. When God pardons Sin, he removes the Guilt of it from the Sinner; the obligation that lay on him, binding him over to dy, ceaseth: this hath been already made evident.

2. In removing this Guilt, God turns away his Vindictive eye from it: though the Sin remains, and the merit too, yet God will no longer look on him as a Guilty Sinner; he will not see iniqui∣ty in him; the man deserves that he should; but God is resolved that he will overlook it, as a thing out of sight; he hath nothing to lay to the man charge, nor will he hear of any Charge laid against him, Rom. 8.33. and this is aptly exprest by his
covering it, for if he should mark, who could stand? Psal. 130.3.

3. Hereupon the Guilt comes to be utterly lost; it is a strange expression, Jer. 50 20. The I∣niquity of Israel shall be sought for▪ and there shall be none, and the Sins of Judab, and they shall not be found; alas! if search be made, there is enough to be found, that hath been sinful and provoking; but it refers to punishment, which presumeth Guilt, and so there shall be none found. When they are put on trial for their lives, and enquiry is made, What Sins are to be charged on such? the answer is, there are none to be found, they stand condemned for none: and why? for they are cast into the Sea; they are all blotted out of the book of accounts; the Indictment against them is defaced; they are covered as a thing that is buried out of sight, as one that is dead and for∣gotten; they are blotted out as a Cloud, Isa. 44 22. and one well observes, that a Cloud is it self a blot in the face of the Sky, and is therefore blotted out by making it to vanish and disap∣pear: and so doth God by his peoples sins: and this is the covering of them.
2 Who is it that Covers it?

A. It is God, and he only, who can thus Cover Sin. If Covering be forgiving, then it belongs to him alone who can forgive, and that is Gods Pre∣rogative, Dan. 9.9. If it be the Guilt of Sin that is covered, and so covered that it shall never rise a∣gain, or be charged, it must needs be a Divine Work. Sin is a Transgression of Gods Law, and the
Guilt contracted by it is an Obligation to suffer accordingly; and who shall remove it but he? Men may forgive the wrong that is done to them, so far as they are concerned, but they cannot forgive the Violation of the Command of God that is therein perpetrated. Men may indeed Charitatively, or Ministerially declare this forgive∣ness, but they cannot bestow it. It is one of the Letters of Gods Name, Exod. 34.7. Forgiving ini∣quity, Transgression and Sin. We may indeed cover the Sins of our Neighbour, by keeping them Secret, and not divulging them, but that doth not hide them from the Revenging Justice of God, who will for all in due time make a discovery of them, if they be not forgiven by him. And we may cover our own Sins, by denying them, dis∣sembling, excusing, extenuating, justifying them: but this will but aggravate the Guilt of them, and expose us to the more severe punishment, Prov. 28.13 This covering of Sin belongs to Justification; & it is God alone that Justifyeth, Rom. 8.33. And in∣deed God, and no other, hath that cover to throw over the Sins of his people, that can hide them from his revenging eye: Every other cover is but an hiding place of deceit. God therefore challengeth it to himself as his prerogative, Isa. 43.25. I, even I am he that blotteth out thy transgressions. If all the power and authority in the World, Civil and Eccle∣siastical, should Subscribe and Seal an act of Obli∣vion for us, it will signify nothing; no, though the Angels of Heaven should joyn in it. God is Judge of the World, and he can either ratify or
nullify all that is done; his act alone can make it authentick. Hence, though we are to ask forgive∣ness one of another, yet we are not to rest in that, but if we would have our Sins buried, and not digged up again, we must go to him to do it for us.
3. How, or after what manner it is Covered?

A. We are here to consider God as a Righteous Judge, and therefore to do nothing but what is consistent with that Righteousness of his. We read, Rom. 3.26. He is both just, and justifyeth. Now it is one piece of Gods Righteousness as a Judge, to punish the Sinner according to Law; and Guilt binds him over to punishment: how then doth he continue just, and yet cover this Guilt so as it shall not rise against the Sinner to procure his punishment? And the resolution of it is in Sum; That he doth it by casting the Robe of Christs Righte∣ousness over the Sinner, and so covering his Sin out of his sight. And here two things offer themselves to consideration,
1. That the Righteousness of Christ is a Robe suita∣ble and sufficient to cover our Sins.
2. How God casts it over us to this purpose?

1. That the Righteousness of Christ is a Robe suffi∣cient and suitable to cover our Sins. As Sin is com∣pared in Scripture to our Nakedness and Shame, so is Christs Righteousness resembled by a Robe provided to cover it withal: and as it was Sin that first gave occasion for mans needing something to cover his Body, so it introduceth the necessity of Christ to hide the nakedness and filthiness of our
Souls. This is designed by the best Robe, Luk. 15.22. This is pointed at in the White Raiment, Rev. 3.18. And this is the Wedding Garment, Matth. 22.11. Now this Robe is made of the Active and Passive Obedience of Christ, for the matter of it. By the former of these he kept the Law exactly, Fulfilling all Righteousness, Matth. 3.15. He was Holy, Harmless, Undefiled, and without Spot. By the latter he made full satisfaction to the Law in all its demands, by bearing the whole penalty that was threatned in it for Sin. And the sufficiency of this Garment to cover all the Guilt of our Sin herein appears.

1. This Righteousness it self answered the Law in the utmost extent of it; so that it is wide enough and large enough to cover all Guilt. Christ bare the penalty to the full which the Law exacted; he bare the whole weight of that wrath which was due to man for Sin. His Righteousness therefore is able to hide the greatest and most multiplied transgressions out of sight: the Law can ask no more than there is in that, to answer God as a Judge, who is fully pleased with the Righteousness of Christ.

2. There is enough in it to Cloath all that come to him for it. It is called Everlasting Righteousness, Dan. 9.24. because it will hold out as far as there is occasion for it: there may be Garments cut out of it for as many as ask for them, and to spare: it can never have an end: the Vertue of Christs satisfaction is Infinite, Heb. 7.25. All are therefore invited to come for it, and a promise is made that
none that do come shall be rejected. It is called the Righteousness of God, Phil. 3.9. because the person whose it was, or who performed it, was God, and so put a Divine Vertue into it, making it infinitely extensive.

3. This Righteousness was provided on purpose for this end; it was prepared to cover the Guilt of Sin. As the Active Obedience of Christ was to purchase for us the inheritance, so his Passive was to satisfy Revenging Justice on our account, by Vertue whereof our Guilt comes to be hidden out of it's sight, by the casting of this over it. Jesus Christ neither Lived for himself, nor Dyed for himself. The Son of God needed no Active Obedience to Justify him, being a Person above Law; nor did Christ need a Passive Obedience to satisfy for him∣self, as man, being perfectly righteous: He there∣fore Gave himself for us, Gal. 2.20. And this was according to Divine compact, so that it is the de∣sign of it, and it was laid in for this; and thus it becomes applicable to us, and so is every way sufficient.
2. How God casts it over us to this purpose?
A. He doth it by applying this Righteousness to us for our Justification: which is fitly exprest by his Clothing us with it to hide our Sin out of his sight; for in this application,

1. God having accepted of this Righteousness for us, looketh upon it as ours. For this reason Christ is called, The Lord our Righteousness, Jer. 23.6. And said to be made Righteousness to us, 1 Cor. .30. And this is a result from the Everlasting
Crivance of it in the Covenant of Suretiship, i the Father promised to him this reward, is Obedience should redound to the Justifi∣ion of many, Isa 53.11. i. e. As many as it wa be applied unto.

2. Hence in the act of Justification he confers this Righteousness upon us to be ours. Having already accepted it for us, he now bestows it upon us; it first was made ready, and then it is put on▪ So that it is not ours Inherently, but Adherently, o Relatively, it is, in respect to us, not a personal bu a relative Righteousness; and in that regard fitly resembled to a Garment, which is no part of the man, but yet it is his, and put upon him for a covering.

3. In conferring this Righteousness upon us, he Cloaths us with it. He throws it over us, so that we who were before naked, are now arrayed with it, so that all our defects and deformities are hid∣den under it: hence the Apostles expression of being found in it, Phil. 3.9. And it covers us all over, so that whatever faults are in us, they are thus put out of sight.

4. Hereupon he judgeth of us by and according to this Righteousness. He looks no farther, as a Judge than to this: by it therefore we are made the Righteousness of God, 2 Cor. 5.21. We are now, on a relative account, pure, and clear, and spot∣less; Justice hath nothing to lay to our charge, because we, having put on Christ the Righteous, are Righteous in him.
4. What advantage accrues to the person by having his Sins thus covered?
A. Much every way: in particular,

1. He is, in the Law account, as if he had never Sinned. For, whatever he hath been and the Law hath nothing to accuse him of; which cannot be proved, is in the Laws account a if it were not, and that which is hidden cannot be proved: when once Sin is covered, there is none to accuse us, for if God will not, who shall? if he hath nothing to charge on us, we are safe: but he saith, I see no Iniquity in the person.

2. Hence he is out of the danger of Condemnati∣on. Rom 8.1, 34. Condemnation is properly a Sentence past by the Judge, upon a person Convict∣ed to be Guilty, dooming him to suffer penalty according to the mind of the Law: So that where there is no Guilt, there can be no Condemnation; and where there is no Transgression chargable, there can be no Guilt found.

3. Hence flows great Peace of Conscience. It is the foundation on which our deliverance from the terrours of an accusing Conscience is built: when that tells us we have thus and so Sinned, & thereby provoked God, it is hereby pacified, when it can look on all this Sin as covered. Now the Spirit of Bondage, which is rooted in every unpar∣doned Sinner, is remedied, Rom. 8.15. The Soul hath the ground of inward Tranquillity notwith∣standing all; and hereupon he can, with the more humbling sense, mourn for his Sin, whiles he can mourn as one that hath a good hope, and is not sunk in despondency.

4. He hath great liberty of access with bold∣ness to the Throne of Grace; there is such a li∣berty which Gods Children enjoy, Heb. 4.16. and this is that which principally contributes to it. It is sin that makes us afraid. When our first Parents were naked, they hid themselves, Gen. 3 8. but now being thus cloathed, their shame and fear is taken away. When we know that our sin is covered, we need not be terrified with the thoughts of the Holiness and Righteousness of God.

5. Hence he shall with greatest comfort appear before the Judgement Seat of Christ in the great Day? and this is a priviledge beyond concep∣on. What is it that makes Sinners afraid of that terrible day, but their Sins, the Guilt whereof makes them fearfully to expect the Vengeance of it? when therefore these are covered, that dan∣ger is removed, and so they can stand upright then; they may hold up their heads with joy, who have these Garments of Salvation thrown over them.
USE I. Learn we hence the miserable state of all Unpardoned Sinners. If this benefit belong only to the pardoned, then surely those that have not gotten into this state are very unhappy; for,

1. All their sins ly open and naked to the eye of Gods Vindictive Justice. We read, Hab. 1.13. That he is of purer eyes, &c. but now all their sins are in his view; they are uncovered; not only Gods all seeing eye discerns them, but his revengful eye looks upon them; they are cast out naked to
the loathing of their persons; God cannot look up∣on them without indignation, he despiseth their I∣mage: Sin is the abominable thing that he hates; and their sin lies before him, and he must hate it. God saith of all their sins, as in Jer. 29.23. I know, and am a witness.

2. Hence when they are judged, they must needs be condemned; this follows upon the con∣sideration of Gods Holiness and Relative Justice. God stands engaged to pass Sentence upon every one as they stand related to his Holy Law: if he sees Sin in men, and upon trial they are found Guilty, they are condemned already, and the Judge of all the earth will do that which is right; it is therefore impossible that they, in such a conditi∣on, should escape his righteous Judgement, for we read, Rom. 2.6. He will render to every man accor∣ding to his deeds.

3. Hence the whole weight of Gods Wrath will certainly fall upon them at last; they can∣not escape it; if he pass the Sentence on them, he will punish them, for that is past in order to Execution. Our Saviour tells us what shall be the issue of the Sentence of the Great Day, Mat. 25. ult. and who knows the forlorn condition of that man, who must thus fall into the hands of the living God? it had been good for that man if he had never been born. Eternal Separation from the pre∣sence of Gods favour, with an endless suffering the Torments of Hell, are his portion from the hand of God; and how dreadful a thing is this?
USE II. Let it serve to awaken and en∣courage Sinners to seek to God for this priviledge. This Doctrine will serve to both these ends, and let me urge it in both respects.

1. Consider, you are all of you by Sin become Guilty before God; all the world by nature are in this condition, Rom. 3.19. Whatever other difference the Gospel priviledges have made be∣tween some and others, which are great, and are not to be despised, but prized; yet herein all are alike. There is never a Child of Adam can ex∣cuse himself from Sin; and Guilt is an insepara∣ble concomitant of Sin, according to the Law un∣der which you are; that hath said, Ezek 18.4. The Soul that Sins, that Soul shall dy; and there is no man, whiles under the Law, that can exemp himself from it.

2. Hence except your sins are covered, you are undone; if Sin rise up and appear against you, when you come to your trial, it will procure that Condemnation which will ruine you for ever, read the Sentence, and that will be enough to convince you of this, Mat. 25.34. Depart ye Cursed, &c. and is not he an undone man on whom this must pass? for as sure as you are Creatures, so certainly will it be executed, if once it proceed from the mouth of the Judge against you.

3. There is no other way but this to have your Sin covered; you may seek to cover it out of sight by your secrecy, but you cannot so put
a blind upon the all seeing eve You may en∣deavour to cover it with oolish pretences and excuses, but he with whom you have to do is not so to be imposed upon; or you may think to hide it under a Repentance and Righteousness of our own, but the Covering will be too short and too narrow; there is nothing but this Robe that can hide it out of Gods sight; Paul therefore was afraid of being found in his own righteousness, Phil. 3.9.

4. There is yet an opportunity to obtain this. God ha provided this Garment, and makes of∣fer of it to Sinners in the day of his patience and grace; and saith, if they will accept of it, he will bestow it upon, and put it on them; this is the great business of the Gospel treaty, in which God by the means, perswades with men to see their ed of it, and the sufficiency there is in it, that they may be willing to accept of it. Jesus Christ will have Sinner to put him on, that their nakedness may not be seen, Rev. 3.18.

5. When your Sin is thus coverd, God can be both just and forgive you; the Righteousness of God is not baulked, but honoured in this way, 1 Joh. 1.9. you may say, how can the Justice of the Law consist with the forgiveness of my sins? it is answered, and it is enough, they are covered with the Robe of Christ's Righteousness; God hath accepted that on your score Christ, in his Humiliation was under the imputation of Sin, and Gods Justice took its satisfaction of him for you, for he was made Sin for us, 2 Cor. 5.21.
And now his Righteousness becomes yours, the Law is satisfied, and your sins hidden under that Satisfaction! Be then perswaded of your need and be not discouraged since he calls you. here,

1. Be sure to renounce your own Righteousness if you are resolved to have that for your cover▪ Christ will not afford you his. Paul plainly inti∣mates the inconsistency of these, in Phil. 3 9 and tells us this was the reason why the Jews mist of Gods Righteousness, Rom 10.3. Say then that your best are filthy rags, Isa. 64.6. resolve that your most specious actions are unprofitable on the account of your Justification, and that you are naked without this Robe.

2. Be sure then to get under the covert of the Righteousness of Christ by Faith; God doth give us this Garment, of his Grace, apply it to us by his Spirit, so we are to put it on by believ∣ing. When we take hold on Christ by believing, we so get under his Shadow, and his Righteous∣ness cloaths us; this then is your great business, to believe on him; so will his Righteousness be∣come yours, and then you are cloathed.
USE III. Here is ground of Consolation to the Children of God, under the deepest sense of their own Sins: And here,

1. This should not hinder, but further your humbling sense of them though God doth not look on them, you should. Soul abasement for Sin, and mourning by reason of it, belong to
that Sanctification which we are all to pursue, if sin be not made vile, and abasing to us, by the appre∣hension of a pardon, we may question whether we do rightly apprehend it.

2. But yet it should comfort your hearts under this sense. Conviction of sin and Guilt joyned together will raise horrors in the Conscience; whereas Conviction of sin, and apprehension of a pardon, together with making us more vile in our own eyes, will afford a support to us, and as the one humbleth us, so the other relieves us, and gives us matter of consolation; for,

1. Christ having cast his skirt over you, your Sins are now for ever covered. When this Gar∣ment is thrown on us, it is never pluckt off again; it is one of those Gifts of God that are without Re∣pentance your Sins are now Sunk, and can rise up no more, they are hidden, and cannot be found again, though they should be sought for.

2. Hereupon his whole Righteousness appears in the sight of God for you. When God looks upon you in him, he sees all the perfect Obedi∣ence of Christ as yours, and it is in the Law ac∣count as much as if you had personally perform∣ed it; for you are accepted in the Beloved, Eph. 1.6 So that the vertue and efficacy of that Righte∣ousness must needs derive to you.

3. Hence your estate shall be determined for ever according to that Righteousness; the Judg∣ment will pass upon that score, and how happy are you then? for if Christ hath by it satisfied the Law for Sin, in bearing the penalties, and
purchased the promised rewards by fulfilling all its precepts, all this shall be yours, and you must needs be happy.

DIV2.HEAD: Pardon consists in the Non-Imputation of Sin. DOCTRINE V.
DIV2.P: PArdon consists properly in the Non Imputation, the taking off the Imputation of Sin. This is the third expression in our Text, by which this for∣giveness is illustrated, viz. Sin is not imputed; and there are two things go in to make this Non-Im∣putation to amount to a pardon.
1. The man was under Guilt before this past upon him. When Sin is not Imputable, the Non-Imputation of it is not forgiveness, for had nothing to be forgiven him, being a righte∣ous person.
2. That this Guilt be taken off, that he cea to be a Guilty person in the account of the Law, and of the Judge. Hence then we may for the clearing up of this Truth, enquire,
1. What is meant by the Imputation of Sin?
2. In what respect all mankind are by nature under this Imputation?
3. What is the state of those who are under th Imputation?
4. How this Imputation comes to be taken off from sinful men?
1. What is meant by the Imputation of sin?

A. We observed, that the word in our Text is often used for reckoning, or charging to ones account, or making a man a debtor for a thing. Man is by sin become a Debtor to the Justice of God, and that expects satisfaction of him, and accor∣dingly chargeth it to his score, that it may call him to an account about it: hence in the Impu∣tation of sin; there are these things to be conside∣red.

1. That Sin is reckoned to the person. Here lies the foundation of it, and hence it is called the Imputation of Sin, because all that follows, flows from it; and hence it is to be observed, that this Imputation being a Forensical act, if the Sin may any way be fastned on the man as his, so that he stands related to it as his own, whether he himself hath actually committed it or no, yet it is justly imputed to him: David did not with his own hand slay Uriah, but yet the Sin is made his, 2 Sam. 12.9. so, if a man owes nothing on a Debt firstly contracted by him, yet if he owes it by Suretiship, it is legally imputed to him.

2. Hence the Guilt of it is charged upon him; and indeed, these two are inseparable in the Law; for looking upon the man as under it, it is impossible that he should be charged with Sin, but he must be reputed Guilty by it: that hath connected the prohibition and the threatning inse∣parably; it hath said, He that Sins shall dy; and it cannot go back from it. Now the Charge of Guilt is nothing else but the assuring of the man,
that he is by Sin become a Subject of Death; so saith the Law, Ezek. 18 4. and a righteous God looks upon such a man, and reckons him bound over to dy.

3. Hereupon the Law rigorously demands its satisfaction of him; the Law is ratified by the Law-giver, and he will give it its claim, and is re∣solved that it shall not suffer loss in a tittle, Mat. 5.28. It saith, I find this man to be under the charge of sin, and so to be Guilty, and I demand Justice upon him: and its mouth cannot be stopt till it hath its demands answered: it is resolved it will have its penniworths out of the person, be∣fore it hath done with him.

4. Hereby he is obnoxious to suffer all the pe∣nalties of the Law, in pursuit of this charge; thu Imputation makes him a prisoner of Justice, and liable to the execution of the threatning: hence said to be in danger, Mat. 5.22. the word signifi∣eth, one that is held in, and kept fast, as one that is im∣prisoned: this execution being the design of, and that in which the Imputation is to determine. Im∣putation claps an arrest upon the man, which will be prosecuted, till Justice hath obtained all its de∣mands of him.
2. In what respect all mankind by nature are under this Imputation?

A. That all are so, is every where asserted in Scripture; and is evident, because the penalties properly belonging to sin are fallen upon them all▪ See Rom. 5.12.14. 1 Cor. 15.22. If all are Sin∣ners, then sin is imputable to all, and if they are
dead by it, it hath surely been imputed. Cer∣tainly that Sin which hath killed a whole world, is imputed to them, how else had they died by it? it includes old and young, persons of un∣derstanding, and Infants, whosoever descends from Adam by natural generation, and hath a reasona∣ble Soul. Now there is a threefold respect in which sin comes to be imputable to mankind, and that righteously.

1. When it is actually and personally commit∣ted by the man. I name this first, because it is most plain and accountable. Sin is properly a Moral Transgression, and supposeth a Law against which the transgression is: and to actual sin it is requisite that it be done by a reasonable creature, capable of acting as a cause by counsel: this there∣fore is not imputable to Infants, for, though they have a reasonable Soul in them, yet it is not in a present capacity of exercising that reason; which want seems not to be a fruit of sin, but a conditi∣on of nature, and had not man fallen, it would in all likelihood have been so; it is therefore said of those that dy in their Infancy, That they have not sinned after the similitude of Adams Transgression, Rom. 5.14. Though how soon they discover their na∣tural corruption is lamentably to be observed; however this extends to all men without excepti∣on, that arrive to any use of their reason; how actual sin will be charged on meer naturals, I can∣not grasp, though the want of the use of reason be a punishment of Adams sin; yet this utterly obstructs the rational acting of such an one, for
that he cannot discern between good and evil. But there is none that ever had the use of reason, but hath abused it by sinning against God, and that both by sins of Omission and Commission: he hath thought, spoken, done otherwise than the Law re∣quires; we have a natural man characterized, Rom. 3.10. &c. And none are exempted from it, we are told, Psal. 58.3. They go astray as soon as they are born, speaking lies; i. e. they are set that way, and it breaks out as soon as they are capable, though in some more notoriously than in others. Now there is no difficulty in telling how actual sin should be imputable to the person committing it; for, if all owe Obedience to the Law, their neglect of, or doing any thing contrary to it, cannot but render them Guilty.

2. When the nature is corrupted by the inhe∣rency of Original Sin. That there is such a thing as the sin of nature is evident from the word of God; it is called Concupiscence or Lust, Jam. 1.14. Indwelling Sin; Rom 7.17 Sin that is alwayes pre∣sent. Verse 21 The Flesh, Joh. 3.6. The body of sin. Rom. 6.6. Of Death, 7.24. The Law in the members, v.23. The body of the Sins of the flesh, Col 2.11. The Old man, Eph. 4.23. Now all these point to the root or fountain from which actual Sin proceeds, and therefore must intend something divers from it; hence we read of Lust Conceived, and Sin the issue of it, Jam. 1.15. Now this Sin is in all Adams Posterity, born after the ordinary course of nature; even Infants, and Naturals too: it is therefore u∣sually called Our Birth Sin, and Our Conception Sin,
according to, Psal 51.5. And it derives from the corrupt fountain from whence we all proceed. Adam defiled himself, lost the Image of God, con∣tracted the Image of Sin, and then he Propagated it, Gen. 5.2. And how should it be otherwise? for Who can bring a clean thing cut of an unclean? Job 14.4. And though this be in one sence a punish∣ment fallen upon us for the first Transgression, yet in it self it is really Sin; it is a Sinful state that we are in by it; the Definition of sin belongs to it, it is Anomy, 1 Joh. 3.4. Mans nature by it doth not answer the Law of Creation And that it is imputed is evident, because it is an Image for which God despiseth man, Psal. 73.20. It is that which they Dy for, Rom. 5.14. Psal. 137 ult. It is certainly in them, and therefore may be charged on them, and the Righteousness of their being found Guilty by reason of it, will one day be made good by him who is Judge of all: mean while the foundation of the equity of it is laid in that which follows: Hence,

3. In respect of the Relation which they bear to Adams first Transgression That our first Pa∣rents became Guilty by their eating the forbidden fruit, is beyond dispute: God had a Sovereign Authority to Command, and they owed him entire Obedience: the Sin it self was great, being a Vi∣olation of the Sacrament of the Covenant, and so the whole Law was transgressed by it: and that they dyed justly none can rationally doubt. But we are given to understand that they drew their whole Posterity into the same Condemnation with
themselves, and this is clear from, Rom. 5.12, 17, 18, 19. Hence, though they were not actually in being, yet that Sin is imputed to them as theirs, and here upon they suffer penally for it: their being born in Sin, and unto misery is a proper resultan∣cy from it. Verse 12. The equity of which Imputa∣tion is, in that God transacted with Adam at first as a Publick Person, in whom he would have all to stand or fall: he therefore represented his whole Progeny, as a King doth his people, as a Father his Family: So that all Humanity being contracted in our first Parents, humane nature be∣came Guilty in and with them, as it was naturally derivable from them.
3. What is the state of those that are under this Imputation?

A. In one word, it is a state of Condemnation. We read, Joh. 3.18. He that believes not, is Condemn∣ed already: By which we are given to understand how it is with all men by nature: all the World stand Condemned before God, and there is not one clear of it, till by Faith in Christ they come to receive a discharge. Now they come under this Condemnation, by the Imputation of Sin to them: for Condemnation hath a respect to punishment, and that always presumes a fault that hath meri∣ted it: and hence, in a fair process, the fault is first charged and proved, and there-upon the Sen∣tence passeth. Now this must needs be a miserable state, if we Consider,

1. That if God impute Sin to any, he will con∣demn them for it; the Righteousness of God as a
Lawgiver and Judge calls for this. God cannot be∣hold Iniquity in any, without detestation of it, Hab. 1.13. And the Sanction of the Law, by which he testifyeth this detestation of his, is that which he hath bound himself unto. As therefore God will charge none but Guilty Sinners, and such as he will convince of Sin and Guilt, so he will doom them accordingly, for in this his Relative Justice manifests it self.

2. That if God do thus condemn, he will pro∣ceed to Execution according to it. He will be as good as his Word, and the Condemned Sinner shall find it so to his cost. God saith as he meaneth, and will therefore do as he faith. When God had past a fearful doom upon Saul for his disobedience, we find what a Seal he clapt upon that Sentence, 1 Sam. 15.29. The strength of Israel will not ly or repent. True, there is room at present, under the Gospel, to have the Sentence reversed by a free pardon; but if this be neglected, and the person comes thus to the bar of Justice at last, he must feel the Execution.

3. The punishment of Sin is tremendous. It is a fearful thing to fall into the hands of the living God. Heb. 10.31. In this punishment God will make it known how hateful a thing to him Sin is, and he will do it by the fearfulness of it: hence these penalties are set forth in the word of God after a formidable manner. God intends in it to shew his wrath, and make his power known, Rom. 9.22. These penalties are expressed as intolerable, Ezek. 22.14.
4. How this Imputation comes to be taken off from Sinful men?

A. In Sum, it is done by the Translation of it from the account of the Sinner, to the account of Christ. There is no other way in which it can be done consistent with the Justice of G: and in this way it may be, and is done for all that are pardoned. Of this we may take this short account.

1. That wheresoever Sin is Imputed, the Law requires satisfaction of the person to whom it is Imputed. This is evident by the nature of impu∣tation, according as hath been explained: for where God reckons Sin to a man, he gives the Law Credit against him for it, and makes him a Debtor to the Law; now the Law being a Rule of Justice, is rigorous, and exacts all its debts: it will not stop its mouth, till compleatly satisfyed▪ Math. 5.18. So that it holds the man fast by ver∣tue of this Imputation.

2. That in Christs Sufferings there was a suffi∣ciency to make this satisfaction. This was necessa∣rily prerequisite, else it could not have answered the demand of the Law for us. For, though it be not therefore our Satisfaction, because there was such a sufficiency in it, Gods acceptance of it being free; yet if it could not have answered the Law in all its demands, it could not have been capa∣ble of Gods acceptance on this account: there was therefore enough in it to do this. Christ Suffered the whole Essence of the penalties that were due to us for sin; he bore the whole weight of the Wrath of God; He was made Sin, 2 Cor. 5.21.
And A Curse, Gal. 3.13. And the Excellency of his person, being Divine, put that Value upon his Sufferings, that rendered them equivalent to the Sufferings of all his people: it the blood of God that was shed, Act. 20.28.

3. That it is consiste with Gods Justice, to ac∣cept of this Satisfaction on the Sinners account. True, the case is Criminal; the Sinner himself deserves to dy, and if God had said he shall dy, and no other for him, it had been very just: but yet it is no wrong either to his Holiness or Justice to say, I will accept of the Sufferings of Christ for the Sinner. If there were nothing more to be said for this than that God hath actually so done, this ought to be enough to stop our mouths, for the Judge of the World can do no∣thing but what is right. But it is acknowledged among men, that a Prince may, if he will, although he may chuse whether he will take another for the offender by exchange, if he freely offers himself: however, God is not bound to the Laws which men are.

4. That God did, by an act of Sovereignty, ac∣cept of Christ for this end. This is evident in the Revelation of the New Covenant, in which we are told that there was such a thing: and all our hopes for Salvation by that Covenant, are built on this foundation; for we are Saved by Christ, we are therefore acquainted with a Covenant of Redemption, on which the New Covenant of Grace is founded; in which God the Father indented with his Son on this account, and made him a promise in
respect to it, that upon his Satisfaction the Vertue of it should derive to them for whom it was, Isa. 53.10. And Christ dyed for this end, Gal. 2.20. Yea he was made under the Law, that so it might exact this of him, in order to our being Redeemed from it, Gal. 4.4, 5. And hence all the penalties he underwent are said to be on the account of Our Sins, Isa. 53.4. And this acceptance was an act of Divine Sovereignty; God acted as a Lord in it.

5. That Christ in these Sufferings bare those relations to his Elect, which rendred them satis∣factory for them; he did all in their stead, and that it might be effectual, he took such Relation that rendred it so in the account of Gods Justice. Now there were two relations that he bare, which comprize in them all that can be required in this regard.

1. Of a Surety; this is expressed, Heb. 7.22 Now a Surety is one that is bound with or for anothe, to respond for him, in case he him fails: and when it refers to cases criminal, he becomes liable to suffer for the principal offender, and upon his so suffering, the Law is satisfied, and he for whom he suffered is released; for no Law requires double satisfaction in the same case: and therefore if the Law take its satisfaction on the Surety, it exempts the offender himself; but there is yet more, viz.

2. Of a Common person or representative, which will yet be a clearer discovery of the fulness of the satisfaction. We therefore have a parallel
made between Christ and Adam, 1 Cor. 15.22. And Adam is said to be a figure of Christ, Rom. 5.14. Now Adam stood as a publick person, repre∣senting his Seed; and so doth Christ represent his: hence as Adams transgression was influential to the undoing of his Seed, so Christ's satisfacti∣on is no less to the making or repairing of his. verse 18.

6. Hence this pardon of sin removes our Guilt to Christ's account, and his Righteousness to ours: this is fully exprest, in 2 Cor. 5.21. He was made sin for us, that we might be made the Righteousness of God through him; i. e. Our sin was charged on him, and his Satisfaction went for it, and his Righteousness was reckoned to us, and so became ours: and this is done by Imputation. Nor can it be in any other way; it must be ours either Relatively, or Inherently; Inherently it cannot be, neither can Christ be the real Sinner, nor can his Sufferings, which in person suffered, be suffered personally by us; but by this transaction it beco∣meth so by Imputation.

7. This is done upon our believing in Christ; they that talk of an Eternal Justification, forget to distinguish between a purpose, a purchase, and the application of it to us, which are not to be con∣founded. It was purposed from Eternity, settled in the Covenant of Suretiship; it was purchased when Christ suffered in our stead, and confirmed to him in his Resurrection, Rom. 4.25. but it is conferred on us, and this translation actually made, on our believing in Christ, Rom. 3.22, 24. and when
it cometh to this, then sin is no more imputed to us; and now, and not till now is the man pardoned man.
USE I. For Information, in a few par∣ticulars

1. Learn hence, that forgiveness of sin is an act of free Grace. It doth not ay, the man in whom there is no sin, but to whom God imputes it ; it supposeth that there is sin, and that God might impute it if he would, and why doth he not? true, it is upon Christ's account, so that it is not free to him, but purchased by him: but in respect of us, there is no merit of ours in the cas, the Psalmist saith, Psal. 130.3, 4. If thou, Lord, shouldest mark iniquity, &c. but for Christ's sake he will not so do; though the man hath been guilty of never so many sins, yet he will not lay any of them to his charge. Justice lets fall its action against him, and dischargeth him from the arrest that was laid upon him; and this is done through Christ, 2 Cor. 5.18. needs th must it be free grace: Well might the Apostle say, Rom. 3.24. Justified freely by his Grace, through the Redemption that is in Jesus Christ.

2 Hence we have a clear discovery of the blessedness of a pardoned man; well might the Psalmist put that remark upon such an one; for indeed one essential part of the misery of Sinner is that they are under the Imputation of Sin▪ Whence ariseth their obnoxiousness to the Fiery Indignation of God, which by this Non-Imputation
they are delivered from; by this the Wrath of God passeth from them; and if God will not charge i, their sin can never bring them into Con∣demnation▪ let them have committed never so many or grat sins, they can do them no hurt on this account; they are thus put out of all danger of hell, and the miseries o that place; and surely he is an happy man.

3. Learn hence the necessity of Christ's passive Obedience, in order to our forgiveness. If he had not suffered, we could not have been pardon∣ed: for such is our relation to the Law of Justice, that if once we have contracted Guilt to our selves, there is a Law Imputation of it to us: and to the aking that off again, nothing less can be necessa∣ry than that the Law be answered; and that re∣quires satisfaction, and will not take up without it. Nor was there any to be found that was able to give in this satisfaction for us, but the Son of God in our nature: if he had not done it, no other could; so that we must have remained un∣der the charge, how then could God have been Just, and yet Justifie us? Rom. 3.26 to him then are we to acknowledge this wonderful benefit.

4. This tells us that forgiveness should not take away, but encrease our self loathing. When God cometh to forgive us, he finds us Sinners, else we should not need forgiveness; and in for∣giving he doth not take away the being of the sin he forgives, or make us inherently righteous, though together with it he ever Sanctifies us; but withdraws the Imputation from it; but still there
is the vileness and the odiousness of it lying before us, and it is not less odious, because God will not impute it; but the consideration of this rich fa∣vour should make us to abominate it so much the more, as it did Paul, Rom. 7.

5. This shews us whence the Consolation of Gods people flows, under the sense of all thei sins. What is the reason why a Guilty Sinner, under the awakenings of Conscience, and disco∣veries of Sin, is terrified, and ready to sink into despair, going up and down as one amazed; when a Child of God sees and knows as much by himself, as many and as great sins that he hath committed, and yet can look upon them, though not without deep self aasement, yet with a great deal of consolation and triumph? Why the one sees not the sin only, but the Imputation too whereas this man can say, that God doth not impute his sins, and so his Soul is comforted on that ac∣count.

6. See here the reason why such as have been great Sinners, and are pardoned, do abound in their love to Jesus Christ; there are none that are more carried forth with ardent affections to him, or more engaged to do or suffer for him; our Sa∣viour gives the reason of it, Luk. 7.47. who e∣ver more engaged in setting forth the riches of Grace tha soul? 1 Tim. 1.15, 16. and why? but because such an one sees that his debt and forfeiture was very great, he was Ten thousand Talents in arrears, his score was formidable, but
it is all crost, there is not one that stands on the Account book against him.
USE II. Let this be to Exhort us all to seek after forgiveness; and one would think it should be enough to put us all upon it to see this secured▪ For Consider,

1. Till your Sins are forgiven, they are impu∣ted. All the Sin, the Guilt whereof derives to any of the Children of men, stands out against them, till a pardon removes it, by taking away the Im∣putation: his whole account abides on record, and is not crossed.

2. Your danger by this is very great. You can∣not answer the Justice of God for one of these Sins, and what an innumerable Company of them is there? So that you go in continual hazard of being laid up by Justice, and prosecuted for them, and then what a woful condition are you in? Our Saviour therefore adviseth, Luk. 12.48, 49.

3. When once you are pardoned, there is no more imputation, that passeth off with it. As God seeth no Sin, so he will charge none: he faith of every one whom he forgiveth, that none of his Iniquities shall be remembered against him.

4. Hence now you may look upon your selves, yea, your sins, without dread. This takes away the ground of terrours, because it blots out the Hand writing that was against you. If, when the Books are opened, there is nothing there to be seen, but it hath the lines of Christ's Blood crossing it, or his Satisfaction and Payment char∣ged
on the other side, all is safe and well. And for help, remember,
1. Your sins must be imputed some where. The Justice of God requires this.
2. Jesus Christ hath enough in his Satisfaction to answer for them, and so to remove the Impu∣tation to his score: there is nothing wanting in his Righteousness to answer all.

3. He offers it to you to be made yours. This is the design of the Gospel treaty, to propose Christ to Sinners; and that is one thing in it, to be their Righteousness, 1 Cor 1.30 And what is this for, but that he may discharge the Debt or Imputation for them?

4. If you would have it, you must go to Christ, and believe in him for it. It comes in by believ∣ing; and Christ is the author of that faith, it must be fetched from him; none but Believers can share in this Imputation of his Obedience. Come then to him, wait on him, seek him to cure you of your Unbelief, and give you faith.

5. And you must renounce all your other de∣pendencies. If you rely on a righteousness of your own, that will never o; Justice is not satis∣fyed with it; it cannot answer the Law for you. Come then with your sins, and confess your insuf∣ficiency, address free grace, put up that petition, Psal 25.11. For thy name sake, Oh Lord, pardon mine iniquity, so shall the Imputation of Sin, cease, and you be made blessed.

DIV2.HEAD: A Pardoned Man is one without Guile. DOCTRINE VI.
DIV2.P: 1. What is to be understood by one in whose Spirit there is no Guile?
2. Whether this have any influence into our pardon or Justification?
3. What evidence this gives to confirm us in the knowledge and belief of our being pardoned and justi∣fied? Of these in order.
1. What is to be understood by one in whose Spirit there is no Guile?

A. This manner of expression is used in the Scriptures more than once, as a Periphrasis of a Godly man: So, Joh. 1.47 Rev. 14 5. The word [Guile] signifies Fraud or Deceit; but is used equi∣vocally, Sometimes in a good, sometimes in a bad sense. There is an honest Craft, 2 Cor. 12.16. and there is a dishonest one, which is pointed at in our Text: and there are many things in which this Guile is practised; there is Guile in mens words, such is Flattery, Psal 12.2, 3 and Lying to deceive, Mic. 6.12. And there is Guile in mens carriages, when they pretend Friendship, and yet lye in wait, Psal. 55.21. And there is Guile in a Profession of Religion, 2 Tim. 3.5. But the root of all this lies at the heart, the falseness whereof puts men upon these Guileful practises: Hence Guile is in the word of God used for Hypocrisy; and to be without Guile for Sincerity: And when this is referred to the Spi∣rit or Soul, it intends that there is an inward prin∣ciple of it in the man which influenceth into his
Life and Conversation; and this points us to that Sanctification that is wrought in the man at Conver∣sion. But for a more particular opening of this, observe these things

1. That in the best of Gods Children here, there is a Body of Death remaining. We have Paul him∣self crying out by reason of it, Rom. 7.24. And what else is intended by this, but the relicks or remins of the Sinful Corruption, which the nature of man is defiled with by the Apostasy? It is that Sinfulness in our nature, which hath in it a repug∣nancy to the Law of God, and cannot yield sub∣jection to it, Rom. 8.7. And therefore is always Warning against the Law in the Mind, Chap. 7.23. And for any meer man, in this Life, to exempt himself from it, is counted a daring piece of im∣pudence, Prov. 20 9. Hence that Hypothesis, 1 Joh. 1.8. If we say we have no Sin, we deceive our selves: And that positive Conclusion, Eccl. 7.20. There is not a just man upon earth, that doeth good, and sinneth not.

2. That in this Body of Death, there is a re∣maining Sinful Guile. It is therefore called a Body, because there is every branch or member of car∣nal Concupiscence in it: for, though the whole of it be mortifyed in Sanctification, yet there is no member of it is wholly destroyed, but remains, though not in its reigning power; and there is no lust but a Child of God shall find the stirring of it in him, if he waily observe himself. Now this Guile is one of those Lusts, or rather a quality of them all; and all men bring it with them into the
World, riveted to their corupt nature, Psal. 58. 4. On which account we have that assertion of the Prophet, Jer. 17 9. The Heart is deceitful above all things.

3. That this Guile doth too often wofully break forth in the Lives of Gods people. And this is a sufficient evidence that it is there, for if they had none, they would never discover any: but how often doth it appear to others? And though it many times acts closely and indiscernibly to the world, yet they themselves might observe it, if they would be acquainted at home▪ Do not good men sometimes act deceitfully in their treating with others? Did not David wofully lye and dissemble to Ahimelech at Nob? 1 Sam. 21. And to Achish, Chap. 23. Yea he was almost gotten into a way of it, whence he prayes against it, Psal. 119 29. And how much of Hypocrisy is a sensible Believer ac∣quainted with in himself, attending on his best du∣ties? How many wry glances, and sinister aims in his prayers, and hearing, and whole Conversation? Whence else is it that he is so often at a loss what to judge of himself as to any thing he doth?

4. In the work of Conversion there is a new na∣ture put into the man. The man that is here said to be without Guile, is to be supposed a true Convert, for there is nothing else but Guile in an Unconverted man; he is wholly acted by a De∣ceived Heart which perverts him. Isa. 44 20. But when God comes to Convert a Sinner to himself, he then makes a powerful and thorough Change in him, 2 Cor. 5.17. This is that which is called
the New Man, in opposition to natural Corruption, which is called the Old man, Eph. 4.22, 24. This is called the New Heart, which God hath said he will give to men in this work, Ezek 36 26. And what else is the New Nature, but a body of Sancti∣fying Graces, infused into the man, by which he is Regenerated, or born again?

5. In this new nature there is no Guile at all. The new Creature is altogether void of Sinful Hy∣pocrisy, it hath nothing in it but what is pure, and sincere, and without Guile. We read, 1 Joh. 3.9. Whosoever is born of God doth not commit sin. i. e. Ac∣cording to his new nature, or the new principle that is infused into him: and it must need appear to be sincere, and not Hypocritical, from the Con∣sideration of the Original of it, and that is from God; it is therefore said to be of him, 1 Joh. 5.4. And Born from above, Joh. .3. And of the Spirit, Vers. 6. And is called the Divine Nature, 2 Pet 1.4. It never consents to▪ much less contrives any deceit or cheat, but is always upright in the exertings of it self. And therefore every Convert∣ed man, so far as he is renewed, so far is he alto∣gether without Guile. As Guile is a quality ad∣hering to every Lust, so integrity is no less to e∣very Grace of the Spirit, that is in the Children of God: their Faith is Unfeigned, 1 Tim. 1.5. And their Love is without Dissimulation, Rom. 12.9. And such are all the Graces which flow from these two, which are the root Graces in a Child of God.

6. The New Nature sets it self against the Guile of the Law in the members, in a Child of God. It
doth not only exert none it self, nor consent to that which the Corrupt part is acting, but it dissents from, and withstands it. There is the Lusting of the Spirit mentioned, Gal. 5.17. And there are two things wherein it discovers this.

1. In the Reluctancy of it against the Corrupt part in us, seeking to suppress and prevent it. So far as Grace is active in the heart of a Child of God, when it meets with a Temptation to Guile or Hypocrisy, it Resists it, bears its Testimony a∣gainst it; influenceth the Conscience according to its present activity, so as to endeavour to Arm it against that part in him, which is eager and vi∣olent for it: and this Paul designs in, Rom. 7. When he speaks of the Good he would do, and the Evil he would not do. And doubtless, many a time, by the help of the Spirit of God, he gets the Victory, overcomes the Temptation, and rejects the Motion with abhorrence.

2. In the Repentance which it brings the man to afterwards. Sometimes the Law of the Mem∣bers is too subtile and strong, and leads the man Captive, and he is drawn into Dissimulation, as Peter and Barnabas were, Gal. 2.12. &c. The deceit∣fulness of his worser part imposeth upon him, and he plays the Fool; but as his Grace had no hand in it, but was meerly overborn; so it recruits again, and what it could not prevent by withstanding, it clears it self of, by Repentance. The Godly sor∣row, bitter mourning, self-abhorrence and morti∣fication he applies to it, witnesseth for him, 2 Cor. 7.11. And this belongs to that Spiritual warfare, with which the Gospel acquaints us.

7. That God, in the New-Covenant, values according to this New Nature. It is true, the Corruption within us, is Originally our own, and we have reason to bewail it as long as we Live; and it gives the Believer a world of grief and mo∣lestation. And when we neglect our Graces, and allow or nourish our Corruptions, God, as a Father, is angry, and Corrects us for it: but however, God looks upon his People according to their Grace. This is the New-Creature, and they are judged such who have it in them. And where there this warfare against Corruption, and Grace exer∣cised in Resistance and Repentance, God is please to accept of us; and though he Charge the other upon our Concupiscence, and will Mortify it us, yet he Chargeth it not so upon the person, to put him out of his Favour for it. And on this account it is, that Paul dares to put it off from him∣self to his Sin, Rom. 7.16▪ 17.
8. Hence such an one is, in a Gospel esteem, one in whom is no Guile. Who,

1. Hath been Regenerated by the Spirit of God, and so hath a principle of saving Grace in him. A Godly man, and one without Guile sound the same thing in Scripture language: he is there∣fore so called, Context, verse 6. for by vertue of such a saving change, the man comes to have a Right Spirit in him, as it called, Psal. 51.10.

2. Hereupon he cordially and sincerely pro∣pounds the Glory of God as his last end, in his whole course. Though he may miss it in the ap∣plication in many things, yet this is the general
scope of his life, and he studieth it daily; this is the great concern that lies upon him, 1 Cor. 10.3. And this is the natural inclination of the new na∣ture in us: for it was put into us to enable us to Glorify God, and hath therefore in it a tendency to the end it was Created for, and accordingly prompts us hereunto.

3. Hence he abhors every thing in him that draws to the contrary. He finds enough and too much in himself which is molesting of him, and sometimes wofully too hard for him; but he is grieved at it, carries it about as his burden, and cries out by reason of it; yea he is vile in his own eyes on this account, as he, Job 41.5. ac∣counts it his misery, that he is so unhappily chained to it.

4. Hereupon he lives in the practice of the mortification of this deceitfulness. As he doth not allow it, so he cannot be quiet for it, but seeks to have it destroyed. We are commanded to morti∣fy the lusts in us, Col. 3.5. and he makes it his business to do so, he fights against it, he brings it to the Cross of Christ to be crucified, he prays hard against it, Psal. 119.29. he hates it, v. 128. Such an one, in Gods gracious account is one in whose Spirit is no Guile.
2. Whether this have any influence into our pardon, Justification?

A. There is occasion to make this enquiry here, because the disputes about it, which began from the first planting of the Churches by the Apostles,
are not yet at an end; nor do Papists only conti∣nue to maintain their Doctrine of merit, and th confounding of Justification with Sanctification; but there are others, who call themselves Protest∣ants, and are not willing to be counted Arminia neither; who go about to depreciate the free Grace of God in pardoning and justifying of us▪ who, whiles they ascribe all to Christ as the me∣ritorious cause, yet find the matter of our Justifi∣cation in us, which they would have to be our Sanctification, and New-Obedience, our faith and Repentance, and Holiness: and they make these not only necessarily concomitant, but an essential part of our Justification. Give me leave then to clear up this matter, and shew the mistake of such an opinion in the following Conclusions.

1. That Justification and Sanctification are two distinct benefits flowing to us from Christ. How∣ever vain men have confounded them, yet the Scripture speaks of them as divers priviledges one from the other, so 1 Cor. 1.30. Christ indeed is made both Righteousness and Sanctification to us, but they are two things▪ and applied to us after a different manner. We are Justified relatively; we are Sanctified really; we are Justified by Imputati∣on, we are Sanctified by Infusion; Justification is a Garment thrown over us, Sanctification is by a new principle put into us; Justification is a Change in our state, Sanctification is a Change in our nature; in the one we are made legally innocent, in the other we are made inherently holy; hence the oe is said to be an Act, and the other is called a Work
by our Divines: because the one passeth upon us Declaratively; whereas the other operates in us Effectually.

2. That both of these derive to us from the same fountain of free grace. Mans whole Salva∣tion doth so, Eph. 2.8. and both of these do ap∣pertain to it; that Justification is a fruit of meer Grace, we are plainly assured, Rom. 3.24. And hence pardon is to be sought of God, or for his own name sake, Psal. 25.11. And our Sanctification hath the same original too, for it is a product of his meer good pleasure, Jam. 1.18. Grace there∣fore, which is the same thing, is given of God, Psal. 84.11. God ows neither of them to us, we ave no way obliged him to bestow them upon us rather than others. We have nothing but Sin, and Guilt, and pollution cleaving to us in our na∣tural state, when God comes to pardon and puri∣fie us; quickning is bestowed on them that were the Children of wrath, Eph. 2.1, 3. How then should our Sanctification, or being without Guile, possibly contribute any thing to our Justification or Par∣don?

3. That they are both of them applied toge∣ther in or upon our Effectual Vocation. They are contemporaries: for though Divines do allow them an order in the handling of them, and an order of nature, and accordingly give the priority to Justification; yet there is no distance of time be∣tween the one and the other, by their acknow∣ledgment; and they are reckoned as be∣nefits joyntly flowing from our Effectual Cal∣ling;
and indeed it is in Regeneration, that we pa from death to life; there it is that we are quickned; and there is a double life that we pass to, accord∣ing to the double death that past upon us: we were dead in the Law, by the Condemnation de∣nounced on us, but now we are made to live by a pardon, in which we are Justified; and we were dead in trespasses and sins, spiritually, and now we are made to live to Holiness by a new inspiration; and if we are no sooner Sanctified than Justified, how can our Sanctification afford any matter for our Justification?

4. That because pardon belongs to Justification, hence it must needs have a respect to a Righte∣ousness from whence proceeds▪ We have al∣ready taken notice of the difference between mens pardoning a Criminal, and Gods forgiving a Sinner: their pardon is not a Justification, , theirs proceeds from mercy, his fro mercy tempered with Justice; theirs is entirely prerogative, but his hath a respect to a Law to which he must be just in it, Rom. 3.26. and this refers not to his Soveraign Justice barely, which is nothing else but his Supremacy, but his Relative Justice, as he is Law giver, and hath constituted a way of procedure with his Creature. In this therefore there must be a Righteousness regarded by him, to which he hath an eye in the very par∣doning of the Sinner, and that Righteousness must be such as will answer it, so that mercy and truth may meet together, &c. Psal. 85.10.

5. That this Righteousness can be no other but
that perfect Righteousness which was required in the Covenant of Works. God did in the First Covenant, that was made with man in our first Parents, constitute the Rule of Righteousness be∣tween him and man; and to that Rule it was that the promises and threatnings were annexed; and hence the procedure of Gods Relative Justice with man, must be according to the tenour of that; when therefore God comes to pardon and justifie a Sinner, that is the Righteousness he proceeds upon: the question is, may this be done, and the honour of the Law be salvd? and the resolution of it is, that if there be a Righteousness to be pre∣sented for the person, that will fully answer the demand of the Law, and may be accepted as his, there will be no injury done to the Law; but if not, it will suffer by it. If it bate but a jot or tittle, it is so far a loser, and for that reason our Saviour assures us that it shall not, Mat. 5.18.

6. That the most eminent sincerity of the Chil∣dren of God, doth not amount to such a Righte∣ousness. And if this be so, here is reason enough to deny it to be the meritorious or material cause of pardon and Justification; for, if it were per∣fect, it could not merit for us a pardon, because we owe it: but if it be imperfect, it cannot be reputed a Righteousness at all, with respect to the Law-Covenant. It is certain, that the Righ∣teousness which that required was such as is without the least flaw or defect, and we see how straitly man was obliged, if he hoped to Escape the Curse of it, Gal. 3.10. One
failure spoils it, and makes it become Un∣righteousness. Now all our Sanctification at present is imperfect, and hath mixtures of Sinful defile¦ment adhering to it. It is a Ragged thing, Isa. 64. 6. Jam. 3 2 When we are most without Guile, there is a mixture of Guile; so that the holiest of men have dreaded, and deprecated a rigorous Law procedure with them, as knowing that they could not stand it, Psal. 130.3. & 143.2. It is an act of Gods rich Grace to accept of the best and most sincere duties that we do; and if there were not a Christ in whom they are accepted, it would not be: there is a pardon that must be continued and ap∣plyed to them, else we had no hope: the Defile∣ment of the Holy things of Gods Israel must be ex∣piated.

7 That the Righteousness of Christ doth alone answer this. This doth, and none else can: this is the Righteousness of God, viz. of Gods providing and of him who was God; it was perfect in it self, it answered all the Laws demands, it com¦plied with both the Sanctions of it, it gave the Justice of God the greatest satisfaction that could be: he did all that the Law required, and suffered all which that threatned in case of sin: it was such a righteousness as no other but the Son of God in our nature could offer; and hence our pardon can be influenced by no other but this, nor can the matter of our Justification be any thing else, because nothing else can stand for ▪

8. That the Commendation and Reward which
Christ will give to the Holiness of his people at the Great Day, belongs not to their Justification, but their Glorification. There will be such a thing, Math. 25.34. &c. But all this is done after their Justification, and when they are in a state of Grace and Favour, and under the priviledges and promi∣ses of the New Covenant. Now, in that New Co∣venant, although there be no worthiness in us, and all our duties are but our duty, and we Unprofita∣ble, Luk. 17.10 Yet our Father who by his Spirit worketh our works in us, and giveth us the Grace to Live without Guile, and to Serve him in upright∣ness of Heart, accepts of his own works in us, gives us the Commendation of them, and bestows a re∣ward upon us, to let us know, that our labour hath not been in vain; yet it is not a reward of Debt, but of Grace. Hence that observable difference, Rom. 6.23. The wages of Sin is Death, but the gift of God is Eternal Life, through Jesus Christ our Lord: But this and such like Scriptures are abusively ap∣plyed to our Justification: for that proceeds accor∣ding to the Rule set down by God in his Law, being answered by a Surety for us; whereas Glorifica∣tion is another thing, and is bestowed on such as were before Pardoned and Sanctified, and made meet for the inheritance, Rom. 8.30.
3. What evidence our being without Guile giveth, to confirm us in the belief and knowledge of our being Pardoned or Justifyed?

A. That Justification and Sanctification are joynt benefits flowing from Effectual Vocation,
hath been already observed: Hence that which gives evidence to our calling, will do so to all the fruits that derive from it; for Christ and his benefits go together, and in our calling the Covenant is made between him and us, and we are united to him, and he becometh ours; and so Justification, Adoption, &c are ours Now one way to know our calling, is by the things that accompany Salvation, Heb. 6 9. i. e. By the fruits in us that infallibly follow upon true Conversion: and those fruits that are evidential are specially to be sought for in Sanctification. For, though Justification and Adoption are benefits bestowed immediately upon Vocation, yet, being Relative they are not self evidential, but must be prove by something that is inherent in us. It is true in Justification we are at Peace with God, Rom. 5. And thence flows peace in our own Consciences▪ but there is a false peace that some please them∣selves withal; and we must therefore seek for that which will witness ours to be true, for which we must look further. And in our Adoption we Receive the Spirit of Adoption, enabling us to call God Father, Rom. 8.15. But yet there are those who pre∣tend to this, and are indeed of their Father the Devil, Joh. 8.43, 44. We must therefore enquire whether it be indeed the Spirit of God that bear∣eth witness in us; and for this also we must find something in us to evidence it; and where should we seek for this but in our Sanctification? For as for our Glorification, that is a resultancy from the three former, and we must by them be established
in a firm belief and comfortable expectation of it; and if the proof of the two former must be by our Sanctification, the clearing up of this must be so too, Heb. 12 14. Holiness without which no man shall see God.
